content.webTitle: Jailbird and The Big Man and the Scream Team

fields.headline: Jailbird and The Big Man and the Scream Team
fields.bodyText: "THEY ARE IN PRISON, THEY WANT TO BE FREE" The Leicester City players accused of sexual aggression in Spain will have to spend two further nights behind bars after their court appearance was finally set for this Thursday. There had been hopes that Paul Dickov, Keith Gillespie and Frank Sinclair would be released on bail today, but the judge involved in the case is awaiting the results of forensic evidence being reviewed in Madrid. He also has 300 pages of evidence and statements to sift through, meaning the players will have spent seven nights in Sangonera prison by the time the charge reaches court. There is also the prospect of the trio facing their accusers in a direct confrontation at the Palace of Justice in Cartagena as Spanish law permits such a meeting. "It is possible," said Luis Ruiperez, the man representing the players, who also confirmed there wouldn't be a decision on the players' bail application until Thursday at the earliest. Having visited the players at the jail in Murcia this morning, Ruiperez maintained they were "in good health," and added: "They are in prison, they want to be free." According to some reports, the men have spent time playing football with other inmates. Meanwhile, Leicester chief executive Tim Davies returned to Spain last night determined to ensure "justice can be done" and "the right facts come out". "I get a sense that the lawyers are more optimistic at present," he said. "I think resolution can be a number of outcomes. Either everybody returns back to England totally free of any charges, they might return back to England to face trial at another date, or it may be that the players stay in jail a little bit longer." Davies also confirmed that the players were being supported by their partners, with Dickov's wife seeing her husband today for the first time since his arrest. * * * * * * * * * * * * QUOTE OF THE DAY "Oliver needs me. Just as a single drop of ink colours 100 litres of water, I want to snuff out the hatred in the stadium with my love" - Ahead of Bayern's Big Cup bombardment in Madrid, Oliver Kahn's young girlfriend Verena Kerth fills the pages of Bild with love and claptrap. * * * * * * * * * * * * UNLUCKY MAN Unless you're Mrs Fergie or a Manchester-United-supporting MI6-agent with time, our taxes, and - if David Shayler's any guide - a few pounds to burn, you probably won't have an intimate knowledge of Sir Alex Ferguson's recent movements. However judging by the day United have had, the Fiver predicts the following: on waking Fergie grimly stared at a mirror, which shattered. He then skidded haphazardly along a polished floor, accidentally opening an umbrella as he did so before - warrhhh! - tripping out of the front door, landing head-first under an open ladder and picking up exactly 13 bruises as a black cat skipped across his path. Yep, it hasn't been Old Claret Face's lucky day. For starters, Uefa is to appeal against itself over Roy Keane's one-match suspension. Yes, you read that right. Apparently [Fiver dons anorak] under article 50 of their disciplinary regulations, Uefa have the power of appeal against verdicts taken by their disciplinary panel and zzzz are asking for Keane's challenge to be considered as assault, which zzzzzz would mean a ban of at least three matches - not the greatest news for United ahead of tonight's big Big Cup match against Porto. But that's not all Ferg's had to put up with, because TWO managers have been trying to outdo him - HIM! - in the mind-games stakes. First Porto coach Jose Morinho weighed in with the faux-coy: "It's difficult for me to understand why United are so worried, they are the better team; they have everything. Why are they afraid?" And then Arsenal's Arsene Wenger was seen lobbying the FA to take the Big Two's FA Cup semi-final away from Villa Park and to the Millennium Stadium - much to United's displeasure. Still, it's not all bad news - United's chief exec David Gill says that United won't have to revise their budgets if they lose tonight. "We haven't forecast to get to the quarter-finals so it won't impact on what we have in our internal projections for this year," he admitted. Judging by United's recent form, that's probably wise. * * * * * * * * * * * * STILL WANT MORE? Check out the Oliver Kahn Gallery - then send us your Stan Collymores! http://football.theguardian.com/gallery/0,8555,1161035,00.html Subscribe to the Fiver's cricketing cousin, the Spin! http://sport.theguardian.com/thespin/idx/0,12496,1165552,00.html * * * * * * * * * * * * THE RUMOUR MILL Manchester United are preparing a £25m-plus-Nicky Butt swoop for Wayne Rooney, which means he's definitely on his way to Chelsea. To fill Paul Sturrock's still-pungent Plymouth boots, the club will poach Neale Cooper from Hartlepool. And in a move the Fiver predicted several months ago, free agent Davy Oyen is on the verge of joining Heusden Zolder. First for transfer tittle-tattle, that's your fearsome Fiver!! * * * * * * * * * * * * NEWS IN BRIEF That flabby Leicester fan who ran on to the pitch to "confront" Ian Walker and then fall over like a punch drunk piglet during City's 5-0 tonking by Aston Villa has been fined £350 and banned from all football grounds for three years. Glasgow Polis have confirmed they'll be taking no action against Rangers defender Maurice Ross following an incident during Sunday's Old Firm derby. He allegedly hoofed a ball into the crowd at a Celtic fan and hit her on the arm. And Sheffield Wednesday may be £512bn in debt and reduced to begging with a tin and mangy whippet at Meadowhall, but they're not so desperate that they need Ken Bates' Russian millions. "When he jumps in the water, the sharks jump out," scoffed chairman Dave Allen at the club's annual meeting. * * * * * * * * * * * * TONIGHT'S TV & RADIO ITV1: Big Cup live - Man U v Porto (7.30pm) Today's Nightmare Hell was penned by an idiot, although he'd prefer we call him Young Archie. Big Cup highlights (11.30pm & 1.25am) "I had an interview in the other week," he begins, struggling manfully to place all the words in the right order. Football League Extra (3.25am) "I had previously met the chief and viewed the company set-up - this interview was a lunch with the Chair of the Board." Shexhy and Liberated Dutch Football (4.30am) Quite how it reached that stage is a mystery, given what follows, but we're clearly getting ahead of ourselves. Carry on. Sky Sports 1: Netbusters (6.30pm & 11pm) "Well, it was in a posh building in the Executive Club on the 28th floor. I found the private lift, pressed 28 and watched the little red numbers whiz by as it sped without stopping to the top floor. Gillette Soccer Special (7.30pm) "I looked the business - smart suit, briefcase, two shoes," he continues, "only when the lift reached 28, the door didn't open. Instead, I heard a voice saying, 'Can I help you, sir?' You're On Sky Sports (10pm & 1.30am) "I replied, 'Yes, I have an appointment for 12.30pm with Mr Appleby', only nothing happened. Football Asia (12am) "Funny, I thought, assuming it must be strict security practice where you had to state your business before they opened the doors. I was suitably impressed. Sky Sports 2: Big Cup live - Juve v Deportivo (7pm) "Then I heard the voice again, 'Can I help you sir?' This time there was an edge in my voice as I repeated my answer. Eurosport: Big Cup (6pm) "But still nothing." Radio 5 Live: Sport On 5 (7pm) Eh? Etc. Talksport: Football First (7pm) "It was then that I realised that the doors had opened behind me and a receptionist was speaking to me. I'd been replying to the closed door in front of me - all this in view of the Club's reading lounge, where my interviewer was sitting, peering over his newspaper!" Newstalk 106 (www.newstalk106.ie): Off The Ball with Ger Gilroy (7pm) He doesn't say whether he got the job, but then he really doesn't need to. Send more Interview Hell/Revenge emails to: the.boss@theguardian.com, and we'll put into practice several years of expensive journalism training by cut-and-pasting one of them into place. * * * * * * * * * * * * SUBSCRIBE TO THE FIVER You can subscribe and unsubscribe at www.footballunlimited.co.uk/Fiver/Redirect * * * * * * * * * * * * CONTACT THE FIVER If you want to contact the Fiver, email the.boss@theguardian.com. * * * * * * * * * * * * GIVE ME CONVENIENCE OR GIVE ME DEATH The Fiver was written by Nick Harper and Sean Ingle.
